transcripts.message:
DECLARATION, in order to secure the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832.

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS.

COUNTY OF WORCESTER, SS.

        ON this 14th day of September in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty two, personally appeared in open court, before Hon. Nathaniel Paine, Court of Probate, now sitting Jonathan Howse of Paxton in the County of Worcester, and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged seventy years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th, 1832.

        THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. That he was born 30 Sept. 1761 in that part of Rutland now Paxton where he has resided ever since.
        That in the autumn of 1777 his father, Paul Howse, now decased, enlisted for seven months, in the Army of the Revolution, & went to Springfield, Mass. At the expiration of one month he had been transported to Brookfield, Mass. his abramature Jonathan Howse, at his father's request, on account of his ill health took his place as his substitute at said Brookfield; and there performed a term of service of six months in the _____ _____of stores deposited at that place. The only duty performed was to stand sentry, which he fully fully performed for the above third term at the expiration of which time he was honourably dismissed.
        Officers who had command of the troops stationed at _____ Brookfield during that term were Lieut. Peter Davis of Rutland and Lieut. Freeman of Sturbridge. Silas Chafflin, now of Holden was with him in the same service during the said term; Levi Hathaway, of North Brookfield was with him a part of the time; and his _____ Joseph Howse was well acquainted with the fact of his services at the time it was performed.

[signed] Jonathan Howse 

He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid.
[signed] Nathaniel Paine Judge of Probate for the County of Worcester
[signed] Jonathan Howse

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS.
COUNTY OF WORCESTER, SS.

two - personally appeared in open Court, before

in the County of Worcester and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged seventy
years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the

THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated.

now Paxton where he has resided ever since.

piration of one month, after he had been from home to

at his father's request, on account of his ill health, took

piration of which time he was honorably dismissed.

was with him in the same service during the last
term; Levi Hathaway, of North Brookfield,
was with him a part of the time; and his
brother Joseph Howe was well acquainted with

[signature] Jon.a Howe

transcripts.message:
DECLARATION, in order to secure the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832.

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS.

COUNTY OF WORCESTER, SS.

ON this 14th day of September in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open Court, before Hon Nathl Paine, justice of the Court of Probate, now sitting Jonathan How, a resident of Paxton, in the County of Worcester, and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged seventy   years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th, 1832.

THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated:

That he was born 30 Sept. 1762 in that part of Rutland now Paxton where he has resided ever since.
That in the autumn of 1777. his father, Paul How, now deceased, enlisted for seven months in the army of the Revolution & went to Springfield, Mass, At the expiration of one month, after he had been transported to Brookfield, Mass, his Abraham of his father, How at his fathers request, an account of ill health took his place as his substitute at said Brookfield, and there performed a term of service of six months in defence of stores deposited at that place. The only duty performed was to stand sentry in which he fully performed for the above stated term at the expiration of which time he was honorably dismissed.
The officers who had command of the troops stationed at base of Brookfield during that term were Lieut. Peter Davis of Rutland, and Lieut Freeman of Fitchburg. Elie Chaffee, now of Holden, was with him in the same service during the said term; Levi Hathaway of North Brookfield, was with him a part of the time; and his own [illegible] Frank Howe was well acquainted with the fact of his service at the time it was performed.
 
                                                 [illegible] Jonathan How

He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid.

Nathl Paine Judge

of Probate for the County of Worcester

transcripts.message:
Deposition of JESSE HICKS

State of Tennessee, Wilson County

On this 26th day of February 1833 personally appeared before me James Taylor Clerk of the Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions for said County JESSE HICKS aged seventy three years, who being duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress passed June 7th 1832.

That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and in the manner following: I first entered the service as a volunteer in the State Line of Virginia, was drafted by Captain William Walls for three months and marched to join the Continental Army at Charlottesville, Va. This was about the 1st day of May 1781, we joined the main army under command of General Green [George Washington], then moved down towards York Town, Va. I do not recollect the names of any particular officers except those above mentioned.

My next service was as a volunteer in the State Line of Virginia, I volunteered at Wythe County Va. for three months and marched to join the main army under General Greene then at Hillsborough, N.C., this was about the 1st day of August 1781. We joined Genl. Green as he was retreating towards the Dan River we crossed said river a few days after, I remained in service until my time expired which was about the first day of November 1781 and was discharged by Captain William Walls at Wythe County Va.

My next service was as a volunteer under Captain James Wilson for six months, marched from Wythe County Virginia to join General Greene in the State of Georgia we joined him near Savannah. I do not recollect the name of any particular officers except those above mentioned. I remained in service until my time expired which was about the first day of March 1782 and was discharged by Captain James Wilson at Wythe County Va.

My next service was as a volunteer under Captain John McClannahan for three months, marched from Wythe County Virginia to join General Greene in South Carolina, we joined him on the north side of Santee River I do not recollect the name of any particular officers except those above mentioned. I remained in service until my time expired which was about the first day of June 1782 and was discharged by Captain John McClannahan at Wythe County Va.

My next service was as a volunteer under Captain Robert Crockett for three months, marched from Wythe County Virginia to join General Greene in the State of South Carolina we joined him at or near Camden I do not recollect the name of any particular officers except those above mentioned. I remained in service until my time expired which was about the first day of September 1782 and was discharged by Captain Robert Crockett at Wythe County Va.

My next service was as a volunteer under Captain John McClannahan for three months, marched from Wythe County Virginia to join General Greene in the State of South Carolina we joined him near Camden I do not recollect the name of any particular officers except those above mentioned. I remained in service until my time expired which was about the first day of December 1782 and was discharged by Captain John McClannahan at Wythe County Va.

My next service was as a volunteer under Captain William Walls for three months, marched from Wythe County Virginia to join General Greene in the State of South Carolina we joined him near Camden I do not recollect the name of any particular officers except those above mentioned. I remained in service until my time expired which was about the first day of March 1783 and was discharged by Captain William Walls at Wythe County Va.

I further declare that I have no record of my service, and that to the best of my knowledge and belief the above is a true statement of such service as I rendered in the Army of the Revolution and that I am not in the receipt of any pension from the United States.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year first above written.

[Signed] Jesse Hicks

We JAMES TAYLOR, Clerk of the Court aforesaid do hereby certify that JESSE HICKS who is personally known to us, signed the above declaration in our presence, and that we at his request have hereunto set our hand as witnesses.

Sworn to and subscribed before me this 26th day of February 1833.

[Signed] James Taylor, Clk
